question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Coming into the course I was completely unfamiliar with warfare- especially within the African context. Through taking Dr. Smith's course, I've learned about how war manifests and can change both the political and social landscape of a country. I've learned how to identify motivations for war and what characteristics allow it to exploit a country's most vulnerable populations. Furthermore, discussing topics such as rape as a weapon of war and the HIV/Aids outbreak across Africa has taught me about the importance of diction in how these issues are discussed and reported in the media. Overall, I've learned how to analyze the complexities of health and warfare in Africa outside of the narrow perspective that the media often portrays of the continent.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We discussed various themes within the class. I learned about the system of apartheid as a whole, how it was upheld, the systems that were put in place to maintain power and control by the white minority, the ways in which the geography of the country played into the creation of apartheid, the role of the Afrikaner identity, and just an overall understanding of apartheid as a system that was upheld. We then discussed the dismantling of apartheid, the role other nations played in this Cold War story, the various movement groups such as the ANC, PAC, Black Consciousness Movement, etc, the important leadership at the time, and the way the state tried to use violence to maintain the system. Lastly, there was an understanding of the long-term effects of apartheid in creating the disparities that exist today, the TRC, and the economic impact.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are someone willing to engage with a lot of reading on a weekly basis, and have any interest in history, this course is a must take. I had next to no knowledge about apartheid South Africa before this course and absolutely loved it, Professor Shapiro really knows her stuff and is very passionate in teaching the subject.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course, and dedicate the time to it. You will learn a lot, and fast, if you keep up with the readings (~100 pages per week) and participate in discussions. I came into the class with little knowledge of South African history, and I am walking away with an understanding of not only the events, but an ability to situate South African history in a broader African and global history. I was pushed to appraise my ideas more critically, and the writing standards are high. Getting an A is not easy in the class, but certainly woth the effort.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a lot of reading, and you will get out what you put in (in terms of engaging with the readings and discussions in classes) but the class is an incredible opportunity to learn so much. There are many lessons to be taken from South Africa, and I think this course is worth taking regardless of your major or career goals.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I absolutely loved this course! Very intellectually stimulating and engaging. The professor is amazing--very knowledgeable, kind, and a great teacher. Just be prepared for a hefty workload, including numerous papers and somewhat dense readings. The work is well worth it, though, and the course really did a great job of instilling a comprehensive understanding of apartheid.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout the course i felt i was able to build my skills of understanding and recognizing the causality of events in their growing importance of a given history. As it pertains to our course that would have been the pre vs. post apartheid eras.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a variety of different things regarding the present state of South Africa. This included economic, political, and gender based issues. I also feel as if I was able to improve my discussion abilities within this course. In other classes, I frequently would answer discussion questions with more of a stream of consciousness approach. However, professor Shapiro helped challenge me and motivated me to consistently provide evidence for my claims.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a robust knowledge of apartheid and its modern legacies in South Africa, an understanding of current political and economic structures in South Africa not limited to but including unemployment, the liaison between big business and labor, the black economic empowerment process, as well as an intricacies revolving around feminism, student protests, and other social movements.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think about contemporary issues in South African society in a multi-dimensional perspective. I also got to practice critical analysis skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of things that I learned across this course and "South African Biographies and Autobiographies" was how to read very efficiently. The reading in this class has been about a book a week. When I first began learning with Prof. Shapiro, I would spend hours and hours on reading and it was difficult to have balance. As I matured in the class, I learned how to read a book within two hours, write reflections in response, and have a critical conversation with my classmates about it. This is a skill I really value. Thank you.I learned a lot about contemporary South Africa. I examined and thought about various themes such as employment, what democracy means, popular engagement, etc. It's required me to think critically about a society I haven't existed within, which was an interesting experience.I also learned how to build a curriculum. In our "What's Missing" paper, Prof. Shapiro asked us to add a theme to our coursework. This made me think about what sources and discussion questions would make for an enlightening and interesting class. I thought that becoming the professor, in a way, was cool.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the way the class is structured with news updates, recaps, reading discussions and open discussions. I also really liked the readings selected - they were conducive to enthusiastic discussion in class. Prof Shapiro is great at directing conversations and letting discussion flow in the classroom.

response_text: Professor Shapiro did a great job facilitating the classes learning. She clearly cared about each student in the class and went above and beyond to help everyone. She made personal connections with each student and worked to maintain those relationships.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Shapiro facilitated our class by having robust discussions about the class topic each week. We also did a weekly news report to keep up with current political events in South Africa, as well as a recap each week on the previous class to continue linking themes, continuities, and disjunctions between the differing topics. I think the roundtable discussions were especially helpful, as well as warm and inviting. While not everyone agreed, there was a lot of respect and civility shown to everyone.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Professor Shapiro would ask the class discussion questions, and we would talk. Traditional seminar. To spur course discussions, we had to contribute to a discussion post for a couple of weeks. Prof. Shapiro and the class served as discussion topics for our conversations. I recommend continuing the conversations. The discussion posts were also cool, I recommend that you keep those. 
To put us into greater conversation with the course material, we each had to do a news report about a contemporary issue and present it to the class. I really enjoyed making mine. I engaged with a lot of primary source to make a good presentation for the class. Also, getting in front of the class, speaking publicly, and answering the class's questions made me have to become a bit of an expert about my issue. I really enjoyed that.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics were incredibly interesting. It was stimulating to learn so much about a society that I've never been to. I learned about perspectives and seen things that are very different from my environment. It put a lot of things into perspective. The papers and assignments were also thought provoking. Why? The "What's Missing" paper, as I mentioned earlier, was critical. The reflection we had to write on one week's sources was also critical. It was critical because it required us to think about the author's perspective(s), what their argument was, and our responses to their arguments. By engaging with the sources that mold our thinking in a critical added an extra, complicated element to course content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it! I went into the class with 0 knowledge on South Africa (except that it's at the Southern end of Africa) and came out of the class being able to write 3000+ words deep dives on issues like the truth & reconciliation commissions, protest movements and contemporary SA social forms. You really learn a lot from the class if you put in the time to read and engage in discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course if you are looking for a public policy elective, or if you are interested in the topic of South African history in general! Easily one of if not my favorite courses of the semester. Insofar as grading is concerned, Prof. Shapiro is a fair grader and an A is attainable, if not exactly easy to get. You do have to spend a fair amount of time doing readings, so keep that in mind.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Knowledge: A history of the development of theory/discourse around human rights, details of human rights violations
Skills: Thinking critically about human rights issues through issue raves, outside events, etc. It's easy to think you're a good person and would support human rights, but this is a very broad claim and as we have seen through issue raves, there's a lot more nuance to human rights as multiple rights have to be balanced with each other.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One new piece of knowledge I gained from this course was the fact that certain human rights are considered non-derogable, including the right to torture. I also gained the ability to use history to understand human rights violation, such as lynchings in America and around the world, to contextualize human rights violation such as the death penalty today. I also learned how to apply a human rights lens to my own community, such as considering how Duke can re-evaluate the monuments it have that uphold white supremacy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was taught how to think of things truly inclusively. One concept Professor Kirk impressed upon us was that human rights are universal for a reason, no matter how bad the person/deed was, their rights are nonnegotiable. Furthermore, I learned a lot about different types of justice, I'm specifically thinking about South Africa and their tribunals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically and try to approach human rights from an objective standpoint. This course opened my mind to different ways of thinking about human rights and how to use history to think critically about the world around us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to codify human rights issues that I never was able to term before. I learned how to analyze human rights issues from an unbiased lens. I learned the evolution of our understanding of human rights issues throughout human history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Defining what having a human right entails and how that has been shaped and reshaped over decades
- Looking at different cultural histories in the context of human rights

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the foundation of human rights, the holocaust from a human rights perspective, refugees and the force of migration, various human rights treaties, the civil rights movement, Death Penalty and death row, and transitional justice in Duke and North Carolina. All of these topics tied into my learning of the importance of human rights and feeling empathetic towards the people in any situation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned more about the specific work that human rights advocates do around the world to promote their mission. We also learned about a lot of the treaties and declarations that govern our current state of human rights. Finally, we dove into human rights violations all throughout history to understand how to prevent them in the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an interesting class. Be prepared to do some reading and, more importantly, to discuss your ideas in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very engaging, with a lot of discussion opportunities and space for you to speak your mind even if it isn't directly related to the topic at hand.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a very good class to learn about the foundations of human rights, and I think all students of any major should take this class as an interesting and perspective-changing class. Try not to miss class, and be engaged as much as possible - it will allow you to learn more!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is an amazing course for anyone who wants to learn more about the world around them. This course really broadened my view of others and what they're going through. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
skills: analytical writing/thinking, group discourse, note taking, reading and interpreting different types of sources
knowledge: learned about the history of the Israel/Palestine conflict, the different actors involved in the region over time, how to think about the issue from different perspectives, and how to think about new frameworks toward peace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading and skimming through a lot of content in a short amount of time, knowledge gathering skills, critical thinking and analysis of texts. Exam preparation skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we learned to examine history through a personal lens by analyzing memoirs and primary sources from varying perspectives. We also learned to engage in texts by completing weekly reading responses. Lastly, we learned to pull out thematic patterns and common threads over the course of Israeli-Palestinian history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me so much more context to understand the situation in Israel-Palestine and helped me to develop the skills to approach understanding longstanding conflict. Learning to think about how to make compromises between groups with so much animosity was incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach the Israeli-Palestinian conflict with numerous perspectives. I learned how to write critically and analyze readings. I also learned the deep history of the conflict which I didn't know existed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I left the class with my analytical writing skills much better than they were previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall structure of the class was pretty clear and cohesive, only thing I would change is make the lectures more relevant to the reading material and make it easier to follow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the lecture style of the class. With an issue as complicated and politically relevant as this one, I think keeping this course predominantly lecture style was really important. It created a standardized base of knowledge that we all could access and understand. I also think the amount of guest speakers we were able to have was truly incredible.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the readings were a very appropriate amount of context for the lectures, and that the course did a good job generally in trying not to tackle too much with such a limited amount of time. The opportunity to speak to guest speakers was incredibly interesting as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the way they taught the class! It was very interactive and made me pay attention. They had speakers a lot which was very cool and nice to switch things up.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would definitely continue using films, clips, and media to teach.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class approaches one of the most hateful conflicts in the world at a time when it is possibly at its worst ever. I also really enjoyed the guest speakers that we had-- we had the honor of speaking to so many people who were leading expets in the field or were directly affected by the conflict.  We were able to engage with them directly and ask them questions about their work, which added new dimension to the topics we were studying.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a course I think everyone should take. It gives you the language and historical context to understand a particularly fraught political moment. If you show up, are an active participant, and pay attention, anyone can do well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class, especially if you feel a deep connection to either side of the conflict. This class will challenge your viewpoints either way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this if you have an open mind about the conflict and want to learn more!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should absolutely sign up for this course.  Dr. Weinthal and Dr. Stein are tremendous teachers who help break down the complexity of the Israel/Palestine conflict without ever minimizing the difficulties of it.  The class will teach you so much about human rights, natural resources, state-building, and the history of one of the most visible global conflicts.  You won't just learn about what happened, you will be asked to engage directly with thehuman dimensions of this conflict and confront the difficult realities of the past and current situation.  This class is a must take.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should absolutely sign up for this course.  Dr. Weinthal and Dr. Stein are tremendous teachers who help break down the complexity of the Israel/Palestine conflict without ever minimizing the difficulties of it.  The class will teach you so much about human rights, natural resources, state-building, and the history of one of the most visible global conflicts.  You won't just learn about what happened, you will be asked to engage directly with thehuman dimensions of this conflict and confront the difficult realities of the past and current situation.  This class is a must take.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The only thing that I learned in this course, was to never take a class taught by Tim Tyson again. While Professor Williams was lovely and kind. Tim Tyson was arrogant, condescending, and the exact opposite of what I would expect to see in a member of Duke Faculty. To start, he went on an anti semetic rant in class where he said "no one talks about jew power, but they quietly have power through the banking industry". While I am not jewish, to see this behavior from a member of such a prestigious university was disgusting. One of my friends in the class is Jewish, and the fact that he had to sit and listen to professor Tysons' ridiculous comments were insane. I also feel very afraid to take action regarding these comments, because Tyson has been extremely vindictive throughout the semester. For example, the majority of the class got an extremely poor grade on the midterm. Instead of trying to help students improve, he said "if I had taken the test I would have gotten a 100". I was one of the fortunate few students who got a B (most got a C, D, or F) however he still refused to respond to an email I sent asking him for help in the class. I hope that there is some training given to Tyson in the future to fix his anti semetic and belittling behavior.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Aside from Tysons awful statements in class, the class was structured horribly. On the first day of class Tyson stated that we would have hard conversations that would help us grow. Not a single real conversation about racial relations in the south happened in this class. Instead, each week Tyson would get up there and ramble for the first 90 minutes of class. He is one of the least engaging speakers I have ever listened to. The only reprieve the class would have from Tysons rambling was when professor Williams would get up and sing. Her singing was amazing and was the only positive of each class. When it comes to the readings, Tyson assigned multiple expensive books that he wrote himself. I know that this is common for most professors, however it was extremely frustrating because the books were no different than what he discussed in class. Additionally his two most popular books have been discredited with his Emmitt Till Book being described in one news article as "Tysons Tall Tales". I have no problem paying for a book that will enhance my learning. However, when the book is filled with lies made up by a professor who does not care about his students I have a problem purchasing them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The lectures consist primarily of Professor Tyson or Professor Williams, sharing their personal experiences and anecdotes related to the topics covered in the readings. While these lived experiences are valuable, the lectures do not delve deeper into the subject matter or provide additional information to enhance understanding. Instead, the professors tend to repeat the same stories and narratives, which does not facilitate further learning or comprehension of the material. The note cards allow students to formulate their own thoughts and make connections to the readings, but during class, the discussions are heavily focused on the professors' perspectives, leaving little room for students to share their insights or explore their connections to the topics.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The syllabus underwent changes once the class began, which is generally not permitted. Initially, a take-home midterm was listed in the syllabus, but about a week before the midterm, it was abruptly changed to an in-class midterm without proper notice or consent from the students. By the time grades were returned for that midterm, the deadline to take the class on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis or withdraw had already passed. Additional assignments were introduced after this deadline, and the final exam was no longer the sole examination, contrary to what was stated in the syllabus. The grading is stringent, with all assessments being written responses, and any deviation from the professor's expected answers can result in low or even zero scores, immediately impacting overall grades. Throughout the course, students do not have access to a visible grade book or platform like Canvas, making it challenging to track their progress as the syllabus and assignments continue to change unexpectedly. To perform well, memorizing terms from the assigned readings is essential, as outside information is often dismissed, and only definitions from the specified texts are accepted for full credit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I realized that while you can increase the amount of resources available in a school, such as standardized test preparation, it doesn't mean that all students will be able to access those resources. Finally, I learned about the difference between school desegregation, integration, and segregation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a ton about the field of environment and conflict. I learned about the importance of accountability in terms of state revenue from natural resources or in terms of an actor being responsible for environmental destruction. I learned about the resource curse and how states abundant in natural resources are more likely to find themselves in conflict. I also learned that conflict doesn't just mean war. It can also include people experience conflict in the form of human rights abuses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about environmental conflict, environmental security, and peacebuilding initiatives wether it pertain to water security, critical minerals, indigenous land, communities being directly impacted, etc. Through the course content I was able to apply it to my writing, discussions, and analysis of readings. I think this class put a lot of things into a different perspective for me because before taking this class I know how bad the environment is impact by out actions, but it's more than just that, everything and everyone is impacted.

Additionally, I enhanced my intercultural communication skills, learning to question existing viewpoints, embrace new ideas, and appreciate diverse perspectives in discussions about global migration.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) General content/knowledge - the overarching topic that we explored throughout this course is one that I hadn't ever really had exposure to. From something as simple as making the distinction between "réfugié(e)" to "demandeur d'asile" at the beginning of the course to now being able to formulate literary and experiential analyses on different genres of works, I have gained the knowledge and more in-depth understanding of the refugee crises and experiences in different time periods as well as different parts of the world. 
2) Ways of thinking - This course has allowed me to exercise critical and evaluative thinking by considering different perspectives towards similar events portrayed by different works and different artists or authors and how the differences can affect the way the audience perceives a given experience. 
3) Skills (language) - my general level of the French language has certainly also improved since I was encouraged to speak in class, which improved my French speaking skills, and there are many writing practices and that enhanced my French writing level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Reisinger's class stood out for its engaging and collaborative environment. She encouraged us to lead the discussions, which shifted the dynamic from a traditional lecture to a more interactive and communal learning experience. This approach not only deepened our understanding but also fostered a sense of camaraderie among us.The respectful debates and discussions we had in class were a highlight. It's a testament to Professor Reisinger's skill that, despite differing opinions, everyone maintained a great deal of respect for each other and for her. Her kindness and thoughtfulness in guiding these discussions were truly appreciated.Additionally, the diverse range of readings she selected were thought-provoking and contributed significantly to the richness of our discussions. This style of teaching, where students feel like active participants in a learning community, was both refreshing and effective. I believe it's a method that would be beneficial in future courses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the instructor and my peers have created an environment that allowed me to more comfortably speak in a language that I definitely didn't feel confident in using at the beginning of the course. By introducing set materials but also allowing for question-guided discussions as well as free-form discussions, this course does an amazing job at keeping all students engaged and thinking. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The service learning was inconsistent, which isn't really the professor's fault but speaks to issues in service in general.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made Professor Reisinger's class particularly stimulating was the way she framed the course with nuanced questions that encouraged deep thinking and analysis. These questions weren't just academic; they challenged us to consider broader perspectives and underlying themes in our studies.Another aspect that greatly contributed to the intellectual stimulation of the class was the context provided for each piece of material we consumed. Understanding the background and nuances of each work enriched our discussions and allowed us to engage with the content on a much deeper level.Moreover, the diversity of our course materials (in terms of periods, places, mediums, and content) was remarkable. From readings to assigned films, each piece was carefully chosen to complement and underscore the message that the migrant experience is far from singular. This variety not only kept the course dynamic and interesting but also broadened our understanding of the subject matter in a way that a more uniform set of materials could not.In short, the course was intellectually stimulating as it was. The diverse materials, along with Professor Reisinger's thought-provoking questions and insightful context, created a rich, multifaceted learning experience.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Constant discussion and opportunities for reflection, always showcasing different perspectives and different means of learning (movies, books, articles, writing, etc.)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was much more work than I thought it should have been, and I felt sometimes that students were graded unfairly. Students who routinely came into class 30 minutes late were never penalized, but students at a higher level of French (or honestly just engagement) were held to a higher standard and punished for failing to meet it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are considering this course, I highly recommend it, particularly for its incredible service learning component. This course is more than an academic endeavor; it offers a unique opportunity to extend your learning beyond Duke and meaningfully engage with the Durham community. The volunteer experience is integral to the course and significantly enhances its value.Through this service learning aspect, you will engage in activities that are much larger than yourself. It is an opportunity to apply classroom knowledge to real-world situations, making a tangible impact in the community. This experience not only deepens your understanding of the course content but also imparts important life lessons in empathy, responsibility, and community involvement.Additionally, this course provides a deeper understanding of Durham's dynamics, allowing you to form connections and gain insights into the community in ways that might not have been previously apparent. It is an enlightening experience that broadens your perspective and fosters a sense of belonging to something greater than the university environment.Therefore, if you are prepared for a course that challenges you academically while offering meaningful community engagement, this course is an excellent choice. You will gain not just knowledge, but also invaluable experiences and connections.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the post-war discussion and knowledge surrounding the Holocaust and WWII in Germany. It was something that I had never learned about; I always learned about the Holocaust, but never the intellectual aftermath. I also learned some film methods and techniques, since this class was an ALP and we watched a decent amount of movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a range of knowledge, skills, and insights that have significantly enriched my understanding of the subject matter. One specific thing I learned was the importance of critical thinking and analysis. Through various assignments and class discussions, I honed my ability to evaluate arguments, assess evidence, and identify logical fallacies, enabling me to approach complex issues with a more discerning eye. Additionally, I gained a deeper appreciation for the power of effective communication. Whether it was through written assignments and class discussions, I learned how to articulate my ideas clearly and persuasively, tailoring my message to different audiences and contexts. Lastly, this course exposed me to diverse perspectives and challenged my preconceived notions. By engaging with classmates from various backgrounds and exploring different viewpoints, I developed a greater sense of empathy and cultural awareness, fostering a more inclusive and open-minded way of thinking. Overall, these three specific learnings—critical thinking, effective communication, and embracing diversity—have not only enhanced my academic abilities but also equipped me with invaluable skills for navigating the complexities of the world beyond the classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the depths of how Germany and German people responded to the Holocaust and, as the course is titled, came to terms with their past. I was able to develop a greater perspective on the Holocaust and a better understanding of everything that went into the persecution of Jews and others during the Holocaust.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I liked learning 1) how to analyze movies/relate them to the historical context 2) more theoretical understandings of guilt, morality, etc. 3) Critical eye towards memorial culture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about controversial issues of the past. I also learned how to put myself in unique perspectives that I have not experienced. I had never really used films to this extent in a class before so it was great to utilize them as a film enthusiast.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of my first times engaging with historical content on a more meta level. As such, I learned a lot about how to compare, contrast and critique secondary sources with a bigger focus on how the authors interpreted events rather than the actual events themselves. I also gained lots of knowledge in the specific domain of the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critically analyze texts and try to hone down on the key messages of the author. Use both fiction and non-fiction sources to come to insightful conclusions. Structure writing in a straightforward and digestible way, while still being able to be creative and thoughtful in writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, close reading, and most importantly a lot of knowledge on what Germany looked like after the Holocaust which (at least in my education experience) had been overlooked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about memory culture and how a country and a people move past horrific history. Specifically, I learned about how Germany reemerged after the Holocaust, different theories regarding German responsibility, and bringing justice to Nazi perpetrators, all within the context of academic articles and popular media such as movies and TV.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: analysis of german film, german guilt and coming to terms with the holocaust, analysis of holocaust memorials

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a side of the Holocaust that I have never discovered. The post-war side, focussing on Germany confronting its actions and past. I have also improved my reading analysis and writing skills while also understanding ways the in-depth interpretation that can be found in sources we have read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about finding and utilizing primary sources. I learned a lot about the history of Germany, and how the holocaust is remembered in different parts of Germany. I also learned a lot about historical and philosophical arguments. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class helps to develop critical thinking. We go through a lot of ethical delimmas that require complex thinking. It also helps develop our debate skills because a lot of the modules do not have a definitive right or wrong answer. Cultrual sensitivity is also a big component.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed so many skills in this course. I learned how to think about global issues ethically and think of smaller solutions to larger problems. I learned how to challenge opinions and previous research. I learned how to always remain culturally sensitive when talking about and presenting global health issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the ethics of global health media, different ways of evaluating the ethics of a situation, and basic principles associated with global health ethics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to take into account different perspectives, form an argument, and practice empathy and understanding for different situations people are going through.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about relevant and practical ethical frameworks applicable to my future academic work in Global Health. I gained new skills in case study analysis and debate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) Different ethical theories and frameworks, (2) How to apply these theories/frameworks to different global health issues and case studies, (3) how to synthesize information from films/documentaries, readings, research articles, etc. to create cohesive arguments

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to apply ethical frameworks, cultural competency when doing research and even learning about other cultures/countries, how to approach ethical dilemmas and when to realize there is no right way-- then in that case, how to apply own moral code

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about ethical frameworks and how to think through case studies through different ethical frameworks. We also learned details of cases such as HIV/AIDS in Cuba, the Ebola Quarantine in Liberia, and the Havasupai diabetes research case.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Knowledge of infectious diseases that I previously didn't even know existed
- Many new frameworks for how to think ethically about Global Health topics
- How to debate both sides of an ethical dilemma

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a great deal about ethical research within the context of global health. I didn’t realize how much research had unethical practices before this class, so it is nice to learn more.  I believe this class also made me better at group work because a majority of our assignments were with a group. Additionally, I believe this course helped me improve in writing concisely because the class quizzes were open answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never taken an ethics of philosophy course before so a lot of the readings and methods of analysis were new to me. One thing that stood out to me that I learned in this course was how to deal with ambiguity. Ethical codes and applications are subject to different interpretations and there is more often than not no right answer. Additionally, this course developed my ability to analyze situations from a variety of perspectives while taking into account the motivations and concerns of different stakeholders.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-what Ebola looked like in the US at the height of Ebola outbreaks in Africa
-principilism and how its core ethical principles can be applied to all different types of ethical situations
-the difference between ethics for bioethics vs humanitarian/social work vs clinical physicians vs public health

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of ethical principles, frameworks, and skills in applying these frameworks to real case studies. I think this course is very meaningful for me, as I have never systematically learned about the ethics in global health. The class activities also include debates, and simulations that enable me to further think about the stakeholders and their perspectives when facing an ethical dilemma.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned an enormous amount about how to approach ethical issues with infectious diseases and also how the characteristics of those diseases affect ethical issues. I learned about this in the context of HIV quarantine in Cuba, the implications of researching Kuru in Papua New Guinea, and how the San people in South Africa created their own ethical framework for researchers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about the ethics of infectious disease, photo ethics, and the responsibility a researcher has to the community they are researching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Stewart split the class time very well. She lectured for half, and the other half was either time to work on a group presentation about the ethics of the case study we are discussing that week or a film to further our knowledge on the case study. I would keep the group presentations - they helped consolidate all the information that we learned because the case studies had a lot of details. I would also continue with the hybrid lecture-work/presentation format. It allowed us to have different dynamics so that we weren't only sitting in a lecture for an 1hr 15 minutes. I also think it is very helpful to have the quiz grades increase incrementally up until quiz 4. I think that takes a bit of pressure of students for quizzes until they get used to the quiz format/flow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoy the learning environment in this class. It is engaging and relaxed, as everyone can ask any follow-up questions during the lecture. And I appreciate the way to conduct group work, especially the debate and the stimulation, whose focus is not on who/which group wins the debate. It is more like an approach to better solving the ethical dilemma or reflecting/ developing the ethic standards. This is unusual for me, compared to some other courses. I learned a lot from this process and I enjoy the process of learning, without too much pressure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this course to students interested in global health studies. This course will give you knowledge in ethics as a field of study, as well as skills to apply the ethical frameworks to real-world case studies, and even future study/ fieldwork. I specifically recommend Professor Stewart's lecture, she is very nice. patient and encouraging, being passionate about ethics studies and teaching. She offers me a lot of help not only within this course but also in many other aspects such as career planing and searching for graduate schools/ programs. You need to spend some time reviewing the content and materials to better prepare for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very reading intensive course and you have to pay attention and take notes when reading. The lecture slides are helpful to guide you, but Dr. Stewart's lectures themselves don't get very far through them. The quizzes are very writing intensive and make up almost your whole grade, and they will shock you at first with the content and quantity. I do think you get used to them over time and grades get better, but if you mess up badly on the first or second quiz, then the whole semester becomes really tough. Definitely a very intense course, so if that's something you want, go for it. You'll learn a lot about ethics, but you will be under pressure for sure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make a quizlet of the frameworks early. Take detailed notes on the slides and look out for hints on the slides for what will be on the quizzes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course has really interesting readings, discussions, films, case studies, etc. However, the quizzes are extremely demanding and time consuming to prepare for, they feel like midterms every single time, and they occur quite frequently for the first 2/3 of the course. Be prepared to take a lot of time out of your schedule to prepare for the "quizzes" and do not try to take this as you easy or chill class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it but study a lot outside of class especially the frameworks.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is enjoyable because Dr. Stewart is great! Just make sure to really study for the quizzes and read the readings as they are assigned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about ethical principles and how to apply them to real-life scenarios (or theoretical ones such as the trolley problem). 
Also, I was challenged by my peer's perspectives on certain issues that were discussed in the class.
Finally, I gained insight into conversations that are taking place right now in the global health space, which is very important to me as someone who wants to go into the field.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about global/cultural traditions and how these perspectives can be applied to ethical issues. I also learned about the ethical tensions of global clinical trials and research with human research. I also learned about all the moral philosophies and ethical frameworks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about numerous ethical frameworks and how to apply them in diverse and complex ethical challenges within global health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Understanding ethical principles, writing about ethics, using ethics to debate for global health points

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to apply ethical principles to difficult health issues and understand both sides of a debate. By thinking about different ethical lenses, I felt like I could better sympathize with opposing viewpoints and form more informed opinions and stances. 
2. I also learned how to frame ethical tensions (with right/right, wrong/wrong, right/wrong) to better get at the core of an issue. I think having this skill has helped me to dissect important issues to truly understand their root. 
3. I developed my skills of gathering knowledge and forming an opinion about a controversial topic. I was able to combine primary sources and scholar analysis with the skills gleaned from this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to effectively research and prepare for debates. I learned how to apply ethical principles to current Global Health situations and experiences. Lastly, I learned how to reflect on my own experiences and be constructive of all the activities I do that seem "commonplace" in the moment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Peck explored the complex history of immigration and was willing to confront topics in a nuanced capacity that is often lost in common discourse around immigration policy. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about immigration history, and the specific ways it affected many immigrant groups in and beyond America. I also learned how to study for an in class writing exam.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to investigate primary sources and incorporate them into a thematic, historical question.
I learned how to contextualize historical, immigration events into a broader theme.
I learned what it means to historicize a certain concept, such as immigrant whiteness or immigrant agency.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has allowed me to think of migration in a much more complex and fluid light and understanding its correlation with policy. This has not only help me contextualize complex policy topics surrounding immigration but also allowed me to engage in conversations about it more empathetically and through a more critical lens than I previously had. These insights have not only changed the way I view US history but the way I approach essay writing of historical contexts and my own family history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- How to analyse documents, historicize primary sources, and introspect on the significance of historical events
- I learned the importance of family histories - the course gave me an outlet to explore that and learn how to place that in the context of a larger, thematic picture.
- the course drew from the class's personal experience and allowed me to learn from varied experiences and viewpoints. It also allowed me to reflect on my own thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about immigration policy and how it is related to foreign policy, how labor movements and immigration intertwine, and I learned so much from my peers about their own relationships with immigration.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) The concept of historicizing, specifically I learned how to critically analyze history and how to look at the causes and consequences of different historical events, acts, social events, etc. 2) Engaging in nuanced discussion. When discussing topics of immigration, I learned about how to truly discuss the concept of immigration to the US and how immigration is not as black-and-white as normally portrayed and rather required more nuanced perspectives. 3) Considering new perspectives. When I first started the class, I came in with preconceived knowledge and perspectives on immigration. However, this class has challenged me to consider new beliefs and perspectives about immigration history, especially for certain immigrant groups that I had not considered as much in the past

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course I was able to learn about different death system practices, and perspectives on death through a harm and repair model. The harm and repair model was essential to our learning and helped us analyze topics in this class from different perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the major things I think of is how we've incorporated nontraditional and community based practices into research, learning and grief. Redefining kinship, practices from Dr. Hagerty's book etc. Along with that is thinking about academics through various lenses, academic and other. Here I'm thinking of Venus in Two Acts and African American Cemetery in New York. Another is just research in terms of the chosen ancestor projects. I hadn't done any time of research which involved interviewing family members and speaking to people in such a personal manor.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about forensic anthropology and the way in which it can coexist with human rights and humanitarian work, and its role in providing healing. I also learned about the death system, and the way in which death is incorporated into various aspects of life, many of which we don't think about. Additionally, I learned about the power of narratives and how one can honor the dead by sharing their story and adding context to who they are.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how death is so much more than the westernized perception I had grow up surrounded by. I learned about the injustices of the death system. I learned about the myriad of forms harm and repair take.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Furthermore, I learned a lot about the history of journalism and its current issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of unique insights from media and industry experts on the state of media and our society today. I got to write a few very fun papers and ideate create solutions to very challenging problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the world of journalism and the current issues the industry faces with trust and retaining ethical standards of content that reflect well on journalism as a whole. I also learned about different mediums of journalism and how to write better papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a lot more about misinformation in the news, which I had not previously known a lot about.
I learned how to construct meaningful, insightful questions for guest speakers, in order to maximise what I gain from these lectures.
I developed how to write in a way that is concise and gets meaning across to the reader of my papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better understanding of the media & journalism industry, a deep dive into some of the issues surrounding trust & polarization, writing tips, creative solutions-oriented thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical media literacy skills, ability to write lively and compelling papers, interesting approaches to media and business

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed an appreciation for the role of local news in my community.
I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I think I learned how to navigate the media more vigilantly. 
I definitely developed deeper critical thinking skills when it comes to how I consume news or "the media". 
I have learned how to apply these skills in different formats of media.

response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the foundations of journalism and journalistic principles, the necessary role fact-checking plays in journalism as well as in our larger democracy, and the evolution of the journalism industry as well as the threats it currently faces.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Guest speakers taught me a lot, but felt like some class lectures were not as stimulating as they could have been. Would have liked to see current events consistently integrated into slides/lectures, as opposed to just having one or two lectures dedicated to dissecting Olivia Nuzzi and Mark Robinson or the election. Also could have included pieces from the Daily Show, Fox & Friends, etc. Also, Phil Boyce was an excellent guest and I would have liked to see some more conservative speakers or assignments from/for conservative sources (though I appreciate it's probably difficult to find people willing to talk to a liberal Duke class).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The range of topics from local to big media and specifically the interaction with guest speakers made it very stimulating.
