question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated hearing the opinions of my peers and would encourage opportunities for us to talk to each other rather than at the teacher. This being said, I think we would've benefited more from group discussions and breaking off into smaller groups so that everyone was able to share their ideas and it could've been more conversational rather than one voice in a big lecture, one at a time. That would've at least been more stimulating to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed how relevant this class was. In my experience, it is rare to be in a class in which the professor is consistently addressing current issues/events. I especially enjoyed this given the recent election cycle. Keeping up with current events is something that I value, so being able to do so through assignments, lectures, and class discussions was highly enjoyable. My only suggestion would be to make the powerpoints more engaging or perhaps limiting them altogether. Although I understand the informational value they bring, they can also not be particularly intellectually stimulating when taking up the entire class period.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I do feel fortunate as this semester felt the most important and relevant to take this class as it was in the months leading up to what feels like the most important election in our lifetimes. Everything we discussed felt perfectly timed and helped inform me to what was going on in the world around me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class! It might be my favorite at Duke so far (and it convinced me to declare a journalism minor).  Bill is a fantastic professor who makes lectures fun and will introduce you to a variety of interesting topics. You'll learn a lot about media and meet super cool people in the industry. I also made good friends in the class thanks to the small-group environment and open discussions. As an added bonus, the workload was always very manageable.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will not practice journalistic writing in this class. This class is a discussion of current events and how political climates shape the media. If you do not like talking about political polarization, do not take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I loved taking this with Professor Bruni! He was a wonderful professor, a great orator, and a kind person. He is so incredibly knowledgeable about the journalism world and I really valued the opportunity to learn from him.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to really think about political issues from both sides, to be as finely detailed as possible in my writing (reading it over and over again), and to come up with good questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave unparalleled insight into the world of news and its impact on the public and policy. More specifically, I learned about the business of the news world, the struggle in maintaining local news, and the polarization in the news world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course. I improved my journalistic writing but more notably I improved my idea generation when planning papers. In receiving one of my lower grades at Duke, I learned how to take constructive criticism on a piece of writing and turn it around for the next assignment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of how to view larger themes in news. I also developed a thorough understanding of the problems in the current news landscape and the decline of local news. I also developed an understanding of the ethical issues underlying journalism and the journalistic process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have never been more informed on the news than I have been in this class. I learned about how local news is dying and the younger population prefers to get a lot of their news from social media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the ethics of journalism, the underlying factors that contribute to its eficacy or lack thereof, and what can be done to make the institution of journnalism better.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The legal and ethical protocols for journalism; how journalistic enterprises function as businesses; how to better recognize biases in journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how important it is to report against your beliefs and stay quick on your feet in this industry. Being part of the news gives you tremendous power, and it is your absolute responsibility to not fall into easy ways of thinking but rather constantly confer with others, challenge yourself, and make bold decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learn all about the news industry. Through the coruse readings, guest speakers and discussion topics, I recognized the important role that news has played and currently plays in our society. I also developed a critical thought process when consuming news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was amazing. I learned countless things throughout the semester, so I'll just name a few. First, I learned that objectivity is a difficult ideal to achieve in journalism, and the closest we can get to total objectivity is by reporting against our own biases and hypotheses. I also learned that there is no single path to a successful career in journalism, and many successful reporters began their professional lives in other careers.

If you put in the work, you'll be rewarded. Furthermore, Professor Tash is extremely open to meeting for office hours, and provides great feedback on assignments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the journalistic imperative of objectivity and impartiality, as well as other editorial standards and why they are so crucial.I gained insight into a wide range of current and historical topics that have played major roles in journalism and the broader world.I widened my perspective about journalism and a lot of recent developments, partially through the regular guest lectures that were informative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing, research, synthesis. This course challenged me in ways I was not expecting. As a senior, I did not feel like I had much to learn, but the daily discussion and 3 core assignments pushed me to think deeper and produce a higher quality product.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the best course I have ever taken at Duke. I learned how to read interresting articles, analyze news sources for credibility, and have intellectually engaging discussions about them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me to think critically about the news, engage with current events, and write concisely.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about local journalism, about journalism ethics, and about ways to make the news more optimistic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: evaluating the news more analytically, historical precedent about the news, journalism specifics from the different speakers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think above all this course taught me the importance of thinking holistically due to the fact that it gave me a greater appreciation for the process of journalism. 2 other things I learned include the importance of being articulate and up-to-date on current affairs as well as the importance of listening and trying to understand opposing viewpoints to the greatest of extents. Without opposing viewpoints, we wouldn't have journalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've learned about the structures of newspapers - how they are divided and structured. 
I have learned about what good journalism is about - having courage, curiosity, and conviction when pursuing the truth.
I've learned about the different types of journalism, from objective news reporting to morning bulletins and opinion editorials, and how journalism can shape history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about journalism and journalistic issues; how to research and form evidence-supported opinions; the values of journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Many of the topics we explored in this course are subjects I engage with daily in my role as news editor of The Chronicle. However, I enjoyed being able to hear the varying perspectives of my peers -- many of whom do not have extensive journalism backgrounds -- on some of the ethical questions I am consistently grappling with. The subjects we discussed included how news agendas are determined and why it's important to balance the slate of coverage on a given day, the importance of anonymous sources and dangers associated with using them too frequently, the obligation to thoroughly fact-check all reporting, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how journalists think in regards to how they write, develop and produce news. One thing that I learned that stands out is that "facts are expensive, opinions are cheap." Being sure to take the time to research is important especially when crafting stories. I also learned the importance of clarity when writing and when reporting. And the importance of follow up questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the principles, economics and different mediums of journalism and how those coincide in a digital world that is constantly evolving.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The Role of Journalism in Society - What function does the news play? How has it shaped history? How do people interact with it? How has it changed?
Interdisciplinary thinking - How to approach complex challenges relating to justice and morality in a world constrained by business and personal influence 
Writing - How to edit our writing to ensure we make every word count and aren't redundant

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped a lot with my writing. Professor Tash took the time to read my paper, mark it up, and offer in-depth feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first journalism class, and I learned a ton about what the field is actually like, the types of stories produced, and how much variety there is in terms of long-form writing, TV broadcasting, podcasts, etc. This class also helped me work on my own writing skills through feedback on my essays, to just getting to read a vast collection of work over the semester and learn from those authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write in a less academic/more journalistic way, critically ask questions, and critically approach news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had know and understood the threats that journalism faces, but I learned more about the complexity and evolution of these threats. It is an insight that I will carry with me as I consume media coverage for the rest of my life. In addition to refining my media literacy skills, I developed news ways of thinking when it comes to understanding the journalism industry. It is not just newspapers and TV outlets, but a blooming industry full of startups and people who simply want to share stories that are interesting to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course did an excellent job of pushing students to think with perspective. As the semester continued on, I realized that in class discussion there was no right answer for anything we were discussing. Debating the moral ethics of journalism is no easy feat, and this class kept me engaged with the world around me, improving not just practical skills like my writing, but also helped me become more of a global citizen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Incredible insight into the journalism world and profession, both through Professor Tash's experience and the amazing speakers
- Writing development: I have never had a professor take so much time and attention in helping us write better. 
- Hearing opinions and experiences differing from mine in respectful and productive ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot through the course of the semester. In fact, as my first and only journalism class of college, I feel grateful it was this one. I learned to think of news as a moral battleground, and received a well-lit tour of the horizon. I learned about partisanship in the news media and to be conscious of framing. I also learned about several important stories on an international, national and local level. Most importantly, I learned about what good journalism and writing looks like, and some tips and tricks to get there.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze news academically, journalism ethics and morals, ways in which to help the journalism industry in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Synthesizing readings, research and writing skills, creative and critical thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a conscious consumer of the news, how to develop my journalistic writing skills, and how to analyze different news articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a tremendous amount about the anatomy of the news business from national to local scales, the shortcomings and bright spots of the industry, and what strong, proper journalism should look like. The guest speakers were phenomenal, shedding light on some of the most pivotal moments in the history of journalism and the impact they have on our world. It was especially interesting to hear these guest speakers speak about the actual process of launching an investigation or expose of a particular subject. This class puts into perspective the indispensable role journalism plays in our society, and that we as a citizenry have an obligation to do our part to preserve that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a STEM major / not having a pub pol or journalism background, this class was super interesting! I learned about the complexities and challenges surrounding both news reporting and journalistic consumption. My favorite aspects dealt with the discussions surrounding the evolution of the news -- how topics such as fact-checking, polarization, and bias have changed drastically in the last decade and especially the last few years. The class was focused on present-day trends not history which I liked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: Professor Tash is a master of this craft, and I could not be more grateful to learn from someone not only as experienced but also as compassionate as him. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to articulate the causes of the local news problem and how to describe the current circumstances and consequences of the local news problem.
2) I gained insight into how the current culture and environment of the journalism landscape incentivizes some journalists to plagiarize or fabricate facts in their stories, like Stephen Glass.
3) I'm now able to better emphasize in what way the journalist of an article is biased—and I can also avow that all journalists and people are biased in some way. For example, you can be biased towards the truth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to think critically about the partisan divide in news and reframe my perspective. I learned how to read articles from opposing viewpoints with an open mind, and consider the bias in journalism. As someone who tries to  naively and impossibly avoid politics, I was also pushed out of my comfort zone to analyze partisan issues and consider the polarization of our news. Go narrow and deep.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that the course struck a perfect balance between class speakers and lecturing from Bill. And throughout both mediums, we were continuously empowered as students to ask questions and contribute to the discussion. Specifically, I think the class speakers are what helped to facilitate student learning. Not only did we hear from journalists and journalist experts, but we also heard from students like us who have ventured into journalism and encountered its problems from a fresh perspective. We heard from right-wing-leaning media owners. We heard from people who were impacted by right-wing media rabbit holes firsthand. Essentially, we got a variety of perspectives on the state of journalism, and this empowered us to use these testimonies to form our own conclusions.I also think all of the writing assignments clearly signaled relevance to the class, and they helped to apply and facilitate our learning. The individual prompts were also well-timed with what we were currently learning about or where we were in the course syllabus/timeline.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was undoubtedly stimulating. The variety of guest speakers with different backgrounds and political leanings combined with the immersive lectures gave us a broad and enriched perspective on the ethical problems of journalism. Most lectures were audiovisual in nature, and the readings and writing assignments we were assigned pertained directly to how we as students consume media and the behind-the-scenes of the media we consume. Finally, we were continuously encouraged to ask and answer questions, which made the class interactive.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

One specific thing I learned in the course is the importance of writing effectively. This means, less is more, and conveying your point with evidence in the least amount of words is the key to a successful writer. You want what you are saying to be impactful, and making it come across in that manner is important. Another thing I learned is game theory, and how to play different types of games and strategies. Before this class, I had minimal knowledge of game theory, and now can relate the concepts I learned in this class to my microeconomics course as well. Lastly, I think another skill that I learned from this class is correlating these games and strategies into human behavior and understanding how people make their decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I enjoyed thinking about the intersection of economics, politics, and philosophy. I learned that these three branches are interconnected, I learned different views on governance, and I learned to questions beliefs about political structure that I had held before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new way of thinking through issues using an economic lens. As someone who has never taken a course in economics before, this was a novel concept for me. I also learned about the concept of the Prisoner's Dilemma, and most importantly how to apply it in a real-world context. Lastly, I learned about the importance of the combination of Politics, Philosophy, and Economics (PPE) when attacking complex problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to compare and contrast different philosophical readings, how to apply economic frameworks to political issues, and we learned about styles of voting and government.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the median voter theorem, different forms of justice, and the origins of social contracts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. How to combine aspects of multiple disciplines

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have taken a class with Prof. Salsman before and something that he is really exceptional at is making individual problems/ideas very multi-dimensional. For example, how you can look at one concept and examine 5 different viewpoints. I also really like how this class is broken up into a bunch of smaller units. Makes the ideas easier to process and think about as well as stay on top of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about game theory, the impact of politics in the economy, and market competition.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First off, in this course I learned the similarities and differences in ideology of philosophers such as Locke, Hobbes and Rousseau. I also learned about game theory, and which situations in the real world possess those same incentives. Along with that, I learned about the "Pareto optimal" outcome, as well as a Nash equilibrium. Lastly, the course covers what government and market failures are, and how we know when they take place. Overall, I learned how to think more philosophically about economic and political policies as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New ways of thinking. I enjoyed learning about political philsophers like Hume and Locke. I enjoyed most of the readings and I thought they provided a lot of unique thought, most notably in the realm of human decsion making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I built on previous knowledge to better understand spatial and theoretical explanations of political economy. I learned how to implement conceptions of justice, marginal markets, and price theories in academic and practical philosophies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new away to approach the world, through a lense of always asking by what standard, and through incorporating a multifaceted approach.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problems often have multiple lenses that they can be viewed through. Depending on which angle issues are approached through, different solutions can be more obvious than others. Synthesizing these different views is a difficult task that often has no "right" conclusion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Identifying the similarities and differences between how liberal thinkers like Rousseau and Locke conceive of the origins and justifications (or lack thereof) of inequality.
2) Being able to describe how Marx, as a theorist, uses and dismantles Smith's thinking while also inspiring thinkers like Martin Luther King Jr., Veblen, and Piketty.
3) Explaining how Tocqueville views equality as a threat to individual liberty.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the class facilitations; they were so engaging and so personal. I really enjoyed essay 2 as well, reflecting on what hope means for me and what hope means in our discussions of business and human rights. One of my favorite moments in this class, one that I have shared with family and friends, is when we talk about what we each hope for in a circle. It's these moments of engaging discussions and sharing personal experiences and viewpoints that make this class so memorable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the articles that we read, and the videos that we watched in class. I think documentaries are such an amazing way to get students passionate about the subject material. I also thought the student facilitations were a great idea, and made it interesting to learn. I also loved writing about hope - giving people the time to write creatively is super important. I was liked discussing topics that were relevant to our own lives, and also Duke. I also loved the speakers we had.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the course was structured in an extremely beneficial way. Professor K made the class really welcoming (and I got to meet a lot of new students) because we opened the class for just a few minutes with an opening question. At the beginning of the course we read a lot of foundational articles/essays that solidified my understanding of Buisiness and Human rights and I really felt like I was able to understand them because we were giving class time (in small groups and whole class) to reflect and work through the arguments (and counter arguments, and flaws in arguments). it was always engaging, especially as the end of the class moved to student-led facilitation. We had such engaging readings and class time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In terms of the learning environment, Professor Katzenstein has a genuine and candid way about her that made me naturally comfortable to share my opinions and analysis of sometimes sensitive or touchy topics in BHR. In this regard, I think she is the perfect instructor for this course and that not many others could carry the classroom in the same way. I'd keep everything about the class the same - the open discussion, small group discussion, and community partner aspects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Knowledge: A history of the development of theory/discourse around human rights, details of human rights violations
Skills: Thinking critically about human rights issues through issue raves, outside events, etc. It's easy to think you're a good person and would support human rights, but this is a very broad claim and as we have seen through issue raves, there's a lot more nuance to human rights as multiple rights have to be balanced with each other.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One new piece of knowledge I gained from this course was the fact that certain human rights are considered non-derogable, including the right to torture. I also gained the ability to use history to understand human rights violation, such as lynchings in America and around the world, to contextualize human rights violation such as the death penalty today. I also learned how to apply a human rights lens to my own community, such as considering how Duke can re-evaluate the monuments it have that uphold white supremacy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was taught how to think of things truly inclusively. One concept Professor Kirk impressed upon us was that human rights are universal for a reason, no matter how bad the person/deed was, their rights are nonnegotiable. Furthermore, I learned a lot about different types of justice, I'm specifically thinking about South Africa and their tribunals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

Dr. Weinthal and Dr. Stein are tremendous teachers who help break down the complexity of the Israel/Palestine conflict without ever minimizing the difficulties of it.  The class will teach you so much about human rights, natural resources, state-building, and the history of one of the most visible global conflicts.  You won't just learn about what happened, you will be asked to engage directly with thehuman dimensions of this conflict and confront the difficult realities of the past and current situation.  This class is a must take.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we learned to examine history through a personal lens by analyzing memoirs and primary sources from varying perspectives. We also learned to engage in texts by completing weekly reading responses. Lastly, we learned to pull out thematic patterns and common threads over the course of Israeli-Palestinian history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Learning to think about how to make compromises between groups with so much animosity was incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach the Israeli-Palestinian conflict with numerous perspectives. I learned how to write critically and analyze readings. I also learned the deep history of the conflict which I didn't know existed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I left the class with my analytical writing skills much better than they were previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write a policy memo and how to work through a policy analysis at national, state and local levels. I also learned how to conduct a touch cost benefit analysis of policies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned specifically about different policies within the US on the environment and how the history of policies have been shaped by public opinion and policy agendas. I also learned about specific ways to analyze political context and policy making to determine how best to achieve a policy agenda, and during the second half of the class, I learned how to specifically analyze the efficacy, equity, and political feasibility of a bill based on its topic and context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about environmental policy in the United States and how to consider the positives and negatives. We learned about policy in the past and how it has changed through the years. Lastly, we thought about how to integrate stakeholders and create implementable policy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write memos and engage with US policy better. I also learned about the history of policy and how it and its partisan relationship has changed over time. Finally I learned how to collaborate better with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze policy and the political process in a way that will really prepare me for my future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about race and its structural and material impact on today's society. I also learned how to synthesize papers and understand that different sources have different perspectives and it is important to look at them critically. I was able to present my knowledge of a topic in depth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how racism is everywhere, how it is structures, and the different stories of different races perceptions of racism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course encouraged me to view world issues from a new, different perspective and has inspired me to continue my education in the sociology field. Specifically, this class taught me that racism is essentially the root of all issues that occur in the world. In addition, this class allowed me to develop my collaboration skills, a valuable skill that has always been and will continue to be used in my academics and beyond.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of eye-opening insights in this class. For example, I gained a vast understanding of the systemic hardships and inequities that Asian Americans have had to face in American history that is simply not talked about in American history. It was also very nice to have certain aspects of my own Asian American experience articulated, validating my experiences of racism and insecurity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course served as an introduction into the social construction of race and how that's played an important role in defining the history of all ethnic groups in the United States. Throughout the semester, we learned about the different laws, social norms, and cultural movements that contributed to the development and continuation of racism. Most importantly, the class discussed the effects of said racism, and explored how they've continued to ensure white supremacy in modernity. Another important factor covered was the concept of color-blind racism, which fundamentally argues that today's racism is maintained through subtle means that appear to uphold equality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a ton about the field of environment and conflict. I learned about the importance of accountability in terms of state revenue from natural resources or in terms of an actor being responsible for environmental destruction. I learned about the resource curse and how states abundant in natural resources are more likely to find themselves in conflict. I also learned that conflict doesn't just mean war. It can also include people experience conflict in the form of human rights abuses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about environmental conflict, environmental security, and peacebuilding initiatives wether it pertain to water security, critical minerals, indigenous land, communities being directly impacted, etc. Through the course content I was able to apply it to my writing, discussions, and analysis of readings. I think this class put a lot of things into a different perspective for me because before taking this class I know how bad the environment is impact by out actions, but it's more than just that, everything and everyone is impacted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about studying history through the lens of anthropology and ethnography, I learned a lot about necroviolence, and I learned how to perform my own qualitative research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about genocide in Argentina, migrant death, and ways to think about harm and repair through memorial and burial practices

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Paradigms for grief, death systems, and repair that never would have occured to me naturally.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course I was able to learn about different death system practices, and perspectives on death through a harm and repair model. The harm and repair model was essential to our learning and helped us analyze topics in this class from different perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the major things I think of is how we've incorporated nontraditional and community based practices into research, learning and grief. Redefining kinship, practices from Dr. Hagerty's book etc. Along with that is thinking about academics through various lenses, academic and other. Here I'm thinking of Venus in Two Acts and African American Cemetery in New York. Another is just research in terms of the chosen ancestor projects. I hadn't done any time of research which involved interviewing family members and speaking to people in such a personal manor.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about forensic anthropology and the way in which it can coexist with human rights and humanitarian work, and its role in providing healing. I also learned about the death system, and the way in which death is incorporated into various aspects of life, many of which we don't think about. Additionally, I learned about the power of narratives and how one can honor the dead by sharing their story and adding context to who they are.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how death is so much more than the westernized perception I had grow up surrounded by. I learned about the injustices of the death system. I learned about the myriad of forms harm and repair take.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Understanding how to critically engage with my own family's stories, how to think outside of the binary in terms of concepts like kinship and memory, and how service-oriented work can have a real impact within the academic sphere.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I appreciated being able to simulateneously develop my own sense of how to engage with the dead and also to think of how society thinks of the dead. I appreciate making the dead more lively exiting the course compared to when I entered. The case studies were heartbreaking but also neccessary as what we learned in class continues to happen today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much more about the holocaust than I could ever imagine. I learned about how there has been hostility towards Jews since the Middle Ages. I learned that scholars are still struggling to figure out if the Holocaust was predetermined or not. I learned about Jewish life before and during the Holocaust.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We thought critically about issues about the Holocaust as well as how those issues have greater implications in today's world. Learn more factually as well as how to ponder moral and ethical questions of why the Holocaust happened and how it could have been prevented.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical research

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) Learned to analyze the Holocaust and other genocides on a deeper, more constructive level2) Focused on themes of courage and perseverance which often are not focused on in the Holocaust3) Evaluated first-hand sources and sources from Nazis themselves

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think historically and how to put different pieces of historical information together in order to form a story of the past. I learned how to research information on historical topics and present them effectively to a class of students.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to connect different historical sources to understand a single event. I also learned how to identify reoccurring themes across different textual evidence. Finally, I improved my presentation skills through our group projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course showed me how to find and critically connect primary sources to make sense of history, broke down the extent to which policy development led to the eventual genocide of the Jews, and taught me the importance of preserving history in a manner that respects the truth of the victims.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Learned how to rethink strategies when it comes to approaching service learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the historical timeline of segregation in education in America and learned to think about issues like Brown v Board critically. I also learned to look introspectively on my own experience within the public education system. I also learned to view resources carefully and consider bias/motives/perspectives that may be hidden.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We studied the history of segregation, ways schools avoided desegregation orders, and ways school districts are re-segregregating today

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about magnet schools, school choice, and charter schools, and the variety of perspectives that individuals had with each. I realized that while you can increase the amount of resources available in a school, such as standardized test preparation, it doesn't mean that all students will be able to access those resources. Finally, I learned about the difference between school desegregation, integration, and segregation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- the history of segregation and its effects today

- understanding of different decisions and rulings across different school districts

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Anderson is a very knowledgeable and caring person. It isn't a difficult class, but it is largely discussion based. I liked how you were able to draw upon your own experiences to participate, but I did worry sometimes about the burden it placed on students from less affluent schools or students of color when they spoke because (as is the case at Duke), they are the minority. I loved when they did contribute because I have never experienced that or had to consider the things they do, but at the same time, that burden shouldn't be placed on them to educate the rest of us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Coming into the course I was completely unfamiliar with warfare- especially within the African context. Through taking Dr. Smith's course, I've learned about how war manifests and can change both the political and social landscape of a country. I've learned how to identify motivations for war and what characteristics allow it to exploit a country's most vulnerable populations. Furthermore, discussing topics such as rape as a weapon of war and the HIV/Aids outbreak across Africa has taught me about the importance of diction in how these issues are discussed and reported in the media. Overall, I've learned how to analyze the complexities of health and warfare in Africa outside of the narrow perspective that the media often portrays of the continent.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learn a lot about africa including the geography, health systems, and current wars.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Although this wasn't marketed as a writing class, I definitely learned how to become a better writer and got a lot of fascinating insight into what *accompanies* war the intricate politics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The impact of war (war, genocide, terrorism, etc) on the health of communities in Africa
2. The psychological and physical impact of war on children (ex. Child soldiers) 
3. Africa's youthfulness as a moderator of political economic, and health-related instability in addition to prosperity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different regions in Africa and how war has affected them. I did not know very much about any conflicts in Africa, so learning about some of the history of conflict zones and the motivations of violence was really interesting. I also learned about how war can affect women and children differentially. I also knew very little about the use of child soldiers in wars.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about Africa from a public health and demographic lens. Learned about war in general and how it has evolved. Learned about the meanings of words.

response_text: This course provided a broad overview of various was war and instances of violence have impacted the public health aspect of Africa. Additionally, the discussion aspect of the course was quite stimulating as Professor Smith encouraged students to raise their thoughts and ideas— which I thought was also a great aspect of this course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed talking about specific places or examples. My favorite reading for this class was the child soldier memoir because it gave real, specific insight into actual experiences. The videos that we watched were also immensely helpful for me because I was able to more accurately visualize the circumstances of the events that we read about.

Secondly, I gained a deeper understanding of South African history, culture, and socio-political issues, which broadened my global perspective. Lastly, participating in class discussions significantly improved my communication skills, as it required me to articulate my thoughts clearly, listen actively, and engage respectfully with diverse viewpoints.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand history from a cause-and-effect lens, understanding the fundamental driving factors behind the fall of apartheid.I learned how to engage in conversations about a variety of topics I am uncomfortable with, and how to present a historical argument with feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Geography of South Africa
2. The nuance in the situation in Apartheid South Africa.
3. Role of religion is assessing what's moral and how its bent or not bend to feed a narrative or justify things.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the rise, the duration, and the fall of apartheid. I learned how to write different styles of essay (oped, reading review, memo, etc.).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a strong understanding of the variables that contributed to the apartheid state and its subsequent effects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We discussed various themes within the class. I learned about the system of apartheid as a whole, how it was upheld, the systems that were put in place to maintain power and control by the white minority, the ways in which the geography of the country played into the creation of apartheid, the role of the Afrikaner identity, and just an overall understanding of apartheid as a system that was upheld. We then discussed the dismantling of apartheid, the role other nations played in this Cold War story, the various movement groups such as the ANC, PAC, Black Consciousness Movement, etc, the important leadership at the time, and the way the state tried to use violence to maintain the system. Lastly, there was an understanding of the long-term effects of apartheid in creating the disparities that exist today, the TRC, and the economic impact.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything apartheid. Would take too long to list.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically consider the history of apartheid, appraising multiple resources and weighing them in a class setting. A key emphasis in this class was being able to articulate, and even be challenged, on certain takeaways and themes from the week's readings and videos.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I gained a thorough understanding of the mechanisms that drove apartheid in South Africa and the implications apartheid had on modern South Africa. 
- I also honed my ability to reason through knowledge and apply it during a classroom discussion, while defending my points and incorporating what my classmates had to say. 
- I also gained experience with writing papers, op-eds, memos, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Additionally I believe I gained very good reading comprehension skills. As a CS major reading is not the most common this to do in major-related classes and taking this course has allowed me to delve into readings and retain information way better.

These components—an approachable instructor and a participatory structure—are invaluable and should be retained in future iterations of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was structured largely through discussion and clarification through asking questions. I loved this format because it allowed for engagement with a wide variety of sources pertaining to apartheid without being too reliant on a solid knowledge base early in the semester. The week by week themed format was also great because if you weren’t particularly interested in a topic, you only had to really focus on it for 1 week. Allowed for a lot of diversity of inquiry.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Shapiro was an incredible facilitator of my learning. Immensely knowledgeable and willing to push me on ideas, I felt like I had to bring my A game to every discussion and class period. I liked the incorporation of different modes of learning -- readings and videos -- and I found the discussions quite enriching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the recap presentations that we did at the beginning of each class. They were a great way to synthesize what had been discussed the previous week, and also allowed me to see how other students were thinking about key themes and issues that arose throughout the course. I also loved the "What's Missing" assignment - I thought it was a great way to allow students some agency over the scope of a final assignment, and provided us with the opportunity to dive into a theme that we simply did not have time to cover in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of the class was phenomenal. I really enjoyed the roundtable-style discussions of the class and found them very intellectually stimulating. I really appreciated how Professor Shapiro made sure that everyone felt comfortable speaking while also giving little nudges to make sure that everyone spoke during the class--it ensured that we all participated equally. I would definitely recommend keeping the class to this small size and retaining the discussion-centric class model. I also enjoyed the online discussion posts that we created beforehand, which helped me plan out the points I wanted to make in class the next day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the discussion-based approach as we were able to delve into topics on Apartheid south Africa in a very unique way. The addition of weekly reviews led by students each week where great to refresh our minds on the previous topics we had covered and also served as a way to maintain certain ongoing topics beyond the class they were assigned to. The what's missing paper was also a great way to express our feelings of what could be a new topic that could be introduced to the class schedule and Dr. Shapiro made sure our ideas where heard of and discussed with the entire class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are someone willing to engage with a lot of reading on a weekly basis, and have any interest in history, this course is a must take. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course, and dedicate the time to it. You will learn a lot, and fast, if you keep up with the readings (~100 pages per week) and participate in discussions. I came into the class with little knowledge of South African history, and I am walking away with an understanding of not only the events, but an ability to situate South African history in a broader African and global history. I was pushed to appraise my ideas more critically, and the writing standards are high. Getting an A is not easy in the class, but certainly woth the effort.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

There are many lessons to be taken from South Africa, and I think this course is worth taking regardless of your major or career goals.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) General content/knowledge - the overarching topic that we explored throughout this course is one that I hadn't ever really had exposure to. From something as simple as making the distinction between "réfugié(e)" to "demandeur d'asile" at the beginning of the course to now being able to formulate literary and experiential analyses on different genres of works, I have gained the knowledge and more in-depth understanding of the refugee crises and experiences in different time periods as well as different parts of the world. 
2) Ways of thinking - This course has allowed me to exercise critical and evaluative thinking by considering different perspectives towards similar events portrayed by different works and different artists or authors and how the differences can affect the way the audience perceives a given experience. 
3) Skills (language) - my general level of the French language has certainly also improved since I was encouraged to speak in class, which improved my French speaking skills, and there are many writing practices and that enhanced my French writing level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Reisinger's class stood out for its engaging and collaborative environment. She encouraged us to lead the discussions, which shifted the dynamic from a traditional lecture to a more interactive and communal learning experience. Her kindness and thoughtfulness in guiding these discussions were truly appreciated.Additionally, the diverse range of readings she selected were thought-provoking and contributed significantly to the richness of our discussions. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the instructor and my peers have created an environment that allowed me to more comfortably speak in a language that I definitely didn't feel confident in using at the beginning of the course. By introducing set materials but also allowing for question-guided discussions as well as free-form discussions, this course does an amazing job at keeping all students engaged and thinking. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made Professor Reisinger's class particularly stimulating was the way she framed the course with nuanced questions that encouraged deep thinking and analysis. These questions weren't just academic; they challenged us to consider broader perspectives and underlying themes in our studies.Another aspect that greatly contributed to the intellectual stimulation of the class was the context provided for each piece of material we consumed. Understanding the background and nuances of each work enriched our discussions and allowed us to engage with the content on a much deeper level.Moreover, the diversity of our course materials (in terms of periods, places, mediums, and content) was remarkable. From readings to assigned films, each piece was carefully chosen to complement and underscore the message that the migrant experience is far from singular. This variety not only kept the course dynamic and interesting but also broadened our understanding of the subject matter in a way that a more uniform set of materials could not.In short, the course was intellectually stimulating as it was. The diverse materials, along with Professor Reisinger's thought-provoking questions and insightful context, created a rich, multifaceted learning experience.
