question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was much more work than I thought it should have been, and I felt sometimes that students were graded unfairly. Students who routinely came into class 30 minutes late were never penalized, but students at a higher level of French (or honestly just engagement) were held to a higher standard and punished for failing to meet it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are considering this course, I highly recommend it, particularly for its incredible service learning component. This course is more than an academic endeavor; it offers a unique opportunity to extend your learning beyond Duke and meaningfully engage with the Durham community. The volunteer experience is integral to the course and significantly enhances its value.Through this service learning aspect, you will engage in activities that are much larger than yourself. It is an opportunity to apply classroom knowledge to real-world situations, making a tangible impact in the community. This experience not only deepens your understanding of the course content but also imparts important life lessons in empathy, responsibility, and community involvement.Additionally, this course provides a deeper understanding of Durham's dynamics, allowing you to form connections and gain insights into the community in ways that might not have been previously apparent. It is an enlightening experience that broadens your perspective and fosters a sense of belonging to something greater than the university environment.Therefore, if you are prepared for a course that challenges you academically while offering meaningful community engagement, this course is an excellent choice. You will gain not just knowledge, but also invaluable experiences and connections.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The only thing that I learned in this course, was to never take a class taught by Tim Tyson again. While Professor Williams was lovely and kind. Tim Tyson was arrogant, condescending, and the exact opposite of what I would expect to see in a member of Duke Faculty. To start, he went on an anti semetic rant in class where he said "no one talks about jew power, but they quietly have power through the banking industry". While I am not jewish, to see this behavior from a member of such a prestigious university was disgusting. One of my friends in the class is Jewish, and the fact that he had to sit and listen to professor Tysons' ridiculous comments were insane. I also feel very afraid to take action regarding these comments, because Tyson has been extremely vindictive throughout the semester. For example, the majority of the class got an extremely poor grade on the midterm. Instead of trying to help students improve, he said "if I had taken the test I would have gotten a 100". I was one of the fortunate few students who got a B (most got a C, D, or F) however he still refused to respond to an email I sent asking him for help in the class. I hope that there is some training given to Tyson in the future to fix his anti semetic and belittling behavior.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Aside from Tysons awful statements in class, the class was structured horribly. On the first day of class Tyson stated that we would have hard conversations that would help us grow. Not a single real conversation about racial relations in the south happened in this class. Instead, each week Tyson would get up there and ramble for the first 90 minutes of class. He is one of the least engaging speakers I have ever listened to. The only reprieve the class would have from Tysons rambling was when professor Williams would get up and sing. Her singing was amazing and was the only positive of each class. When it comes to the readings, Tyson assigned multiple expensive books that he wrote himself. I know that this is common for most professors, however it was extremely frustrating because the books were no different than what he discussed in class. Additionally his two most popular books have been discredited with his Emmitt Till Book being described in one news article as "Tysons Tall Tales". I have no problem paying for a book that will enhance my learning. However, when the book is filled with lies made up by a professor who does not care about his students I have a problem purchasing them.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The lectures consist primarily of Professor Tyson or Professor Williams, sharing their personal experiences and anecdotes related to the topics covered in the readings. While these lived experiences are valuable, the lectures do not delve deeper into the subject matter or provide additional information to enhance understanding. Instead, the professors tend to repeat the same stories and narratives, which does not facilitate further learning or comprehension of the material. The note cards allow students to formulate their own thoughts and make connections to the readings, but during class, the discussions are heavily focused on the professors' perspectives, leaving little room for students to share their insights or explore their connections to the topics.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The syllabus underwent changes once the class began, which is generally not permitted. Initially, a take-home midterm was listed in the syllabus, but about a week before the midterm, it was abruptly changed to an in-class midterm without proper notice or consent from the students. By the time grades were returned for that midterm, the deadline to take the class on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis or withdraw had already passed. Additional assignments were introduced after this deadline, and the final exam was no longer the sole examination, contrary to what was stated in the syllabus. The grading is stringent, with all assessments being written responses, and any deviation from the professor's expected answers can result in low or even zero scores, immediately impacting overall grades. Throughout the course, students do not have access to a visible grade book or platform like Canvas, making it challenging to track their progress as the syllabus and assignments continue to change unexpectedly. To perform well, memorizing terms from the assigned readings is essential, as outside information is often dismissed, and only definitions from the specified texts are accepted for full credit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely learned a lot in this course and was able to continue to grow my thinking and the concept of game theory. One specific thing I learned in the course is the importance of writing effectively. This means, less is more, and conveying your point with evidence in the least amount of words is the key to a successful writer. You want what you are saying to be impactful, and making it come across in that manner is important. Another thing I learned is game theory, and how to play different types of games and strategies. Before this class, I had minimal knowledge of game theory, and now can relate the concepts I learned in this class to my microeconomics course as well. Lastly, I think another skill that I learned from this class is correlating these games and strategies into human behavior and understanding how people make their decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I enjoyed thinking about the intersection of economics, politics, and philosophy. I learned that these three branches are interconnected, I learned different views on governance, and I learned to questions beliefs about political structure that I had held before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new way of thinking through issues using an economic lens. As someone who has never taken a course in economics before, this was a novel concept for me. I also learned about the concept of the Prisoner's Dilemma, and most importantly how to apply it in a real-world context. Lastly, I learned about the importance of the combination of Politics, Philosophy, and Economics (PPE) when attacking complex problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to compare and contrast different philosophical readings, how to apply economic frameworks to political issues, and we learned about styles of voting and government.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Exploring the intersections between various disciplines (Politics, Economics, Philosophy). Interdisciplinary approach allowed me to explore ideas from a new perspective and use critical thinking skills to make judgements

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the median voter theorem, different forms of justice, and the origins of social contracts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to combine aspects of multiple disciplines 
2. How to quickly find specific information from dense readings 
3. How to write commentaries using description, analysis, and judgement

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have taken a class with Prof. Salsman before and something that he is really exceptional at is making individual problems/ideas very multi-dimensional. For example, how you can look at one concept and examine 5 different viewpoints. I also really like how this class is broken up into a bunch of smaller units. Makes the ideas easier to process and think about as well as stay on top of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about game theory, the impact of politics in the economy, and market competition.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First off, in this course I learned the similarities and differences in ideology of philosophers such as Locke, Hobbes and Rousseau. I also learned about game theory, and which situations in the real world possess those same incentives. Along with that, I learned about the "Pareto optimal" outcome, as well as a Nash equilibrium. Lastly, the course covers what government and market failures are, and how we know when they take place. Overall, I learned how to think more philosophically about economic and political policies as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New ways of thinking. I enjoyed learning about political philsophers like Hume and Locke. I enjoyed most of the readings and I thought they provided a lot of unique thought, most notably in the realm of human decsion making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I built on previous knowledge to better understand spatial and theoretical explanations of political economy. I learned how to implement conceptions of justice, marginal markets, and price theories in academic and practical philosophies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new away to approach the world, through a lense of always asking by what standard, and through incorporating a multifaceted approach.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problems often have multiple lenses that they can be viewed through. Depending on which angle issues are approached through, different solutions can be more obvious than others. Synthesizing these different views is a difficult task that often has no "right" conclusion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to analyze and dissect articles and documents and formulate critiques/responses to them.
I learned about different viewpoints on justice and economics from esteemed thinkers throughout history.
I leaned how to write my own opinions with regards to ideas presented in class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was stimulating because it basically combines components of three schools of thought that are taught in education: Politics, Philosophy and Economics. This combination is not forced either, because the topics in class that we debate absolutely stretch across these three areas. I think the course would be even more intellectually stimulating if the students got to participate a little bit more actively in the debates. For example, maybe having one day of class per week dedicated to learning some material of the slides, and the other one being more of a class discussion graded for participation. I think I would retain a lot of the information better through active class debate.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is an amazing course. I enjoyed it and Prof. Salsman is awesome. Super enjoyable discussions and not an overbearing workload. If you are looking for an interesting Econ elective or PoliSci class -- I 100% recommend it. Also, go to class. Prof. Salsman does not require attendance but it is 100% worth going. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are not doing the PPE certificate, don't bother taking the course. Flunch Professor Salsman if you're interested in hearing more about libertarianism, but if you have already taken Political Economics or related courses, don't bother with this one.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To a future student considering this course, I would say definitely take it and preferably in your first two years at Duke. I think it gives you a great foundational understanding of how Economics, Philosophy and Politics are intertwined in society, and based on which of those areas interests you the most, you can take more specific classes in the future targeting that area. It's a course that appeals to a wide range of people, and I would say if you want to become a more critical thinker about how people make decisions in government and just in society in general, take the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class helps to develop critical thinking. We go through a lot of ethical delimmas that require complex thinking. It also helps develop our debate skills because a lot of the modules do not have a definitive right or wrong answer. Cultrual sensitivity is also a big component.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed so many skills in this course. I learned how to think about global issues ethically and think of smaller solutions to larger problems. I learned how to challenge opinions and previous research. I learned how to always remain culturally sensitive when talking about and presenting global health issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the ethics of global health media, different ways of evaluating the ethics of a situation, and basic principles associated with global health ethics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to take into account different perspectives, form an argument, and practice empathy and understanding for different situations people are going through.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about relevant and practical ethical frameworks applicable to my future academic work in Global Health. I gained new skills in case study analysis and debate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) Different ethical theories and frameworks, (2) How to apply these theories/frameworks to different global health issues and case studies, (3) how to synthesize information from films/documentaries, readings, research articles, etc. to create cohesive arguments

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to apply ethical frameworks, cultural competency when doing research and even learning about other cultures/countries, how to approach ethical dilemmas and when to realize there is no right way-- then in that case, how to apply own moral code

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about ethical frameworks and how to think through case studies through different ethical frameworks. We also learned details of cases such as HIV/AIDS in Cuba, the Ebola Quarantine in Liberia, and the Havasupai diabetes research case.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Knowledge of infectious diseases that I previously didn't even know existed
- Many new frameworks for how to think ethically about Global Health topics
- How to debate both sides of an ethical dilemma

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a great deal about ethical research within the context of global health. I didn’t realize how much research had unethical practices before this class, so it is nice to learn more.  I believe this class also made me better at group work because a majority of our assignments were with a group. Additionally, I believe this course helped me improve in writing concisely because the class quizzes were open answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never taken an ethics of philosophy course before so a lot of the readings and methods of analysis were new to me. One thing that stood out to me that I learned in this course was how to deal with ambiguity. Ethical codes and applications are subject to different interpretations and there is more often than not no right answer. Additionally, this course developed my ability to analyze situations from a variety of perspectives while taking into account the motivations and concerns of different stakeholders.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-what Ebola looked like in the US at the height of Ebola outbreaks in Africa
-principilism and how its core ethical principles can be applied to all different types of ethical situations
-the difference between ethics for bioethics vs humanitarian/social work vs clinical physicians vs public health

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of ethical principles, frameworks, and skills in applying these frameworks to real case studies. I think this course is very meaningful for me, as I have never systematically learned about the ethics in global health. The class activities also include debates, and simulations that enable me to further think about the stakeholders and their perspectives when facing an ethical dilemma.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned an enormous amount about how to approach ethical issues with infectious diseases and also how the characteristics of those diseases affect ethical issues. I learned about this in the context of HIV quarantine in Cuba, the implications of researching Kuru in Papua New Guinea, and how the San people in South Africa created their own ethical framework for researchers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about the ethics of infectious disease, photo ethics, and the responsibility a researcher has to the community they are researching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Stewart split the class time very well. She lectured for half, and the other half was either time to work on a group presentation about the ethics of the case study we are discussing that week or a film to further our knowledge on the case study. I would keep the group presentations - they helped consolidate all the information that we learned because the case studies had a lot of details. I would also continue with the hybrid lecture-work/presentation format. It allowed us to have different dynamics so that we weren't only sitting in a lecture for an 1hr 15 minutes. I also think it is very helpful to have the quiz grades increase incrementally up until quiz 4. I think that takes a bit of pressure of students for quizzes until they get used to the quiz format/flow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoy the learning environment in this class. It is engaging and relaxed, as everyone can ask any follow-up questions during the lecture. And I appreciate the way to conduct group work, especially the debate and the stimulation, whose focus is not on who/which group wins the debate. It is more like an approach to better solving the ethical dilemma or reflecting/ developing the ethic standards. This is unusual for me, compared to some other courses. I learned a lot from this process and I enjoy the process of learning, without too much pressure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very reading intensive course and you have to pay attention and take notes when reading. The lecture slides are helpful to guide you, but Dr. Stewart's lectures themselves don't get very far through them. The quizzes are very writing intensive and make up almost your whole grade, and they will shock you at first with the content and quantity. I do think you get used to them over time and grades get better, but if you mess up badly on the first or second quiz, then the whole semester becomes really tough. Definitely a very intense course, so if that's something you want, go for it. You'll learn a lot about ethics, but you will be under pressure for sure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Be prepared to take a lot of time out of your schedule to prepare for the "quizzes" and do not try to take this as you easy or chill class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a robust knowledge of apartheid and its modern legacies in South Africa, an understanding of current political and economic structures in South Africa not limited to but including unemployment, the liaison between big business and labor, the black economic empowerment process, as well as an intricacies revolving around feminism, student protests, and other social movements.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of things that I learned across this course and "South African Biographies and Autobiographies" was how to read very efficiently. The reading in this class has been about a book a week. When I first began learning with Prof. Shapiro, I would spend hours and hours on reading and it was difficult to have balance. As I matured in the class, I learned how to read a book within two hours, write reflections in response, and have a critical conversation with my classmates about it. This is a skill I really value. Thank you.I learned a lot about contemporary South Africa. I examined and thought about various themes such as employment, what democracy means, popular engagement, etc. It's required me to think critically about a society I haven't existed within, which was an interesting experience.I also learned how to build a curriculum. In our "What's Missing" paper, Prof. Shapiro asked us to add a theme to our coursework. This made me think about what sources and discussion questions would make for an enlightening and interesting class. I thought that becoming the professor, in a way, was cool.

response_text: Dr. Shapiro facilitated our class by having robust discussions about the class topic each week. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:

Prof. Shapiro and the class served as discussion topics for our conversations. I recommend continuing the conversations. The discussion posts were also cool, I recommend that you keep those. 
To put us into greater conversation with the course material, we each had to do a news report about a contemporary issue and present it to the class. I really enjoyed making mine. I engaged with a lot of primary source to make a good presentation for the class. Also, getting in front of the class, speaking publicly, and answering the class's questions made me have to become a bit of an expert about my issue. I really enjoyed that.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class!! This was one of the best classes that I’ve ever taken at Duke — and perhaps even the best. The work is manageable, but Dr. Shapiro also has very high expectations so you’ll learn a lot. The class is structured well, the readings are informative and interesting and also manageable. And Dr. Shapiro is an incredible resource — she is more than willing to give you time if you ask for it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a lot of reading. It'll help you learn how to read efficiently. If you don't like to read a lot, then don't take the class.I find South Africa incredibly interesting. If you don't know anything about it, I definitely recommend that you check it out. Actually, I recommend you take multiple classes on it to get various perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about contemporary South Africa including Mandela's presidency and the impact he had on the country, how issues such as xenophobia and gender violence are rampant, and the comparison of apartheid times to post-apartheid times.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about South Africa and global politics from gender-based violence in SA, Labor Protests, and the cruelties of Apartheid. I have become more curious about learning these things just for the sake of knowing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read the specific nuances behind several historical documents, the different perspectives that should be taken into account when reading history, and definitely several stories that I have never considered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course made me more adept at analyzing primary documents, critically thinking about the historical context of a given event, and evaluating my own place in broader historical narratives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed knowledge about how to historicize ideas and themes, and new ways of thinking to understand the complexities of whiteness, mobility, and, migration.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Peck explored the complex history of immigration and was willing to confront topics in a nuanced capacity that is often lost in common discourse around immigration policy. I learned how to read into the history of documents and events to better understand underlying human and political themes surroudning immigration. I also learned a lot, quite simply, about the factual history of US immigration and its development over time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different waves/periods of immigration, the policies associated with each period and the consequences of such policies. We also practiced evaluating and critiquing sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about immigration history, and the specific ways it affected many immigrant groups in and beyond America. I also learned how to study for an in class writing exam.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to investigate primary sources and incorporate them into a thematic, historical question.
I learned how to contextualize historical, immigration events into a broader theme.
I learned what it means to historicize a certain concept, such as immigrant whiteness or immigrant agency.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has allowed me to think of migration in a much more complex and fluid light and understanding its correlation with policy. This has not only help me contextualize complex policy topics surrounding immigration but also allowed me to engage in conversations about it more empathetically and through a more critical lens than I previously had. These insights have not only changed the way I view US history but the way I approach essay writing of historical contexts and my own family history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- How to analyse documents, historicize primary sources, and introspect on the significance of historical events
- I learned the importance of family histories - the course gave me an outlet to explore that and learn how to place that in the context of a larger, thematic picture.
- the course drew from the class's personal experience and allowed me to learn from varied experiences and viewpoints. It also allowed me to reflect on my own thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about immigration policy and how it is related to foreign policy, how labor movements and immigration intertwine, and I learned so much from my peers about their own relationships with immigration.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) The concept of historicizing, specifically I learned how to critically analyze history and how to look at the causes and consequences of different historical events, acts, social events, etc. 2) Engaging in nuanced discussion. When discussing topics of immigration, I learned about how to truly discuss the concept of immigration to the US and how immigration is not as black-and-white as normally portrayed and rather required more nuanced perspectives. 3) Considering new perspectives. When I first started the class, I came in with preconceived knowledge and perspectives on immigration. However, this class has challenged me to consider new beliefs and perspectives about immigration history, especially for certain immigrant groups that I had not considered as much in the past

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think what professor Peck looks for in the writing assignments forces you to do a lot of critical thinking and really delve deep into the meaning of certain historical events/ideologies. The course forces you to think deeply about your own experiences and connect them with the experiences of others in order to better understand history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I think this course helped me understand how to historicize policy on a deeper level, and allowed me to see contingencies (where things could have gone differently)
2. Working and engaging deeply with a variety of primary documents, even if they don't give you the information you're necessarily looking for 
3. This course pushed me to think thematically about historical processes, not just "what happened"

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
building context: learning how to explore the preceding how and why's of an event
analyzing history through a granular lens: looking at individual components when analyzing a bigger picture moment
presenting and analyzing history as a class: working with others to analyze documents, presenting topics individually or with others with emphasis on thematic accuracy

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are a student that needs slides alongside lectures or strict, clear instructions for work, I would note that this class may be a bit difficult for you. However, if you can self-organize I think there is a lot to learn from this course!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to read a lot of heavy-based texts. If you are not a humanities major, this class WILL bore you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Peck has taught this class man times and is clearly a pro. He loves what the teaches, wants us all to learn, and enjoys the ideas we bring to the class more than anything. He's a great professor and the class is a strong opportunity to learn about a complicated topic in-depth.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Around exam season, it can be a little overwhelming to remember all the immigration policies we learned and could be tested on. However, I would suggest flashcards to remember each policy. I would also try and get the readings for each week done by the beginning of the week

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Peck is great!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: In the first half of the course, make sure to do the readings. In an added step, it would be really useful for the midterm if you not only read the materials, but also write down notes on how it connects to a broader theme that we are talking about in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an awesome class that I would highly recommend to any students, especially one that is interested in public policy, general history, and US immigration policy. This class challenges you to rethink many of the ideas that were cemented in your mind about immigration and the history of race and race relations in the country.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! It is a great course that allows you to think about history uniquely. The assignments are interesting and well-spaced. Professor Peck is a great teacher, always willing to help and take the extra step.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the topic of the class is already very interesting, I think the most important insights taken from this course is actually what you learn about the other students in the class. Their stories, perspectives, and passions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in immigration or have connections to the immigration system, this class is very interesting and I highly recommend it. Professor Peck is very knowledgeable about the immigration system and is overall a great person to know and have interesting and meaningful discussions with

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think it's a very interesting course and it's a pretty light workload most of the time. Prof peck is really good about making sure that the readings are manageable and that we have enough time to complete the big writing assignments. There aren't any daily assignments to turn in, just one or two short readings due before class. Oftentimes the readings also end up being really interesting as they are stories of immigrants' own experiences. I think the projects/writing assignments we are assigned are also super interesting and rather enjoyable to do.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have personal experiences with immigration, or just are interested in immigration policy in general, take this course. I think the way Professor Peck constructed this course truly provides a very solid foundation for immigration policy history, and challenges many of the assumptions in public discourse.With that said, if you don't have a real interest in immigration policy, I'm not sure if this is the right class for you. This course does force you to engage with some pretty difficult/complex material and the assignments are not easy (even though the papers are relatively short).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course to learn about one of the U.S' key characteristics: polarizing and deeply historical immigration system. Your personal perspective is valued as a way to also dissect topics. Dr. Peck is great at breaking down barriers and making otherwise intimidating (and maybe taboo) topics digestible. Paying attention, critical writing and analytical skills (or at least the ability to want to improve them throughout the semester) and mindfully participating is key. The class' theme allow for there to be camaraderie; definitely get to know your peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to use other readings to connect with history. I learned to understand other cultures. I learned to see different point of views from different students.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about immigration policy. On a substantive level, I have down some important facts and statistics. On a more interpretive level, I learned how to contextual history in personal narratives and cultural phenomena.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained knowledgability on immigration policies and immigrant perspectives that have shaped modern society and culture in the United States.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
* the experience and history behind different immigrant groups

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I feel as though I also learned how to improve my writing, the feedback we received on papers was always insightful. I also learned how to answer complicated questions through the experiences of others and their stories which is a powerful way of thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of immigration policy in the US and how that shapes so much of the discussion of immigration in the country today. I learned about the powerful stereotypes that exist and how they interact and shape the policy at hand.  I also learned how stories about immigration are told in the US and how that shaped opinions and views of the issue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I literally would struggle to boil this down into three points. This class fundamentally altered and modified my notions of sex and gender, and their place in the economy. In particular, the role of women's unwaged reproductive labor in the paradigm of the modern US service economy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically evaluate different types of labor, especially reproductive labor, through a lens of considering how women are uniquely impacted. I gained a lot of new insights into different professions that are pretty normalized like nannying or surrogacy and how they operate under a capitalist system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained so much insight into the ways that certain sectors of work are "feminized" and how that feminization contributes to its devaluation in society. I also learned a new way to conceptualize the idea of "work." Finally, I learned to think critically about how different types of work are characterized, stigmatized, and viewed in society.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Kathi was a phenomenal instructor. She maintained the perfect balance of lecture and discussion. I appreciated how well she moderated our discussions and encouraged everyone to participate. Another thing that I really appreciated about the classroom environment was that everyone was respectful and open-minded. People felt comfortable disagreeing with each other and it really allowed our class to explore all sides of an issue or debate. Also, Kathi was very welcoming and encouraging of all kinds of contributions. I never felt afraid to speak up because she let us know that every comment was important and valuable to our discussion, no matter how small. She also kept the conversation moving forward and guided it very well to ensure we covered a lot in each class and didn't get stuck in a repetitive loop of everyone repeating the same idea.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to articulate the causes of the local news problem and how to describe the current circumstances and consequences of the local news problem.
2) I gained insight into how the current culture and environment of the journalism landscape incentivizes some journalists to plagiarize or fabricate facts in their stories, like Stephen Glass.
3) I'm now able to better emphasize in what way the journalist of an article is biased—and I can also avow that all journalists and people are biased in some way. For example, you can be biased towards the truth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to think critically about the partisan divide in news and reframe my perspective. I learned how to read articles from opposing viewpoints with an open mind, and consider the bias in journalism. As someone who tries to  naively and impossibly avoid politics, I was also pushed out of my comfort zone to analyze partisan issues and consider the polarization of our news. Go narrow and deep.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that the course struck a perfect balance between class speakers and lecturing from Bill. And throughout both mediums, we were continuously empowered as students to ask questions and contribute to the discussion. Specifically, I think the class speakers are what helped to facilitate student learning. Not only did we hear from journalists and journalist experts, but we also heard from students like us who have ventured into journalism and encountered its problems from a fresh perspective. We heard from right-wing-leaning media owners. We heard from people who were impacted by right-wing media rabbit holes firsthand. Essentially, we got a variety of perspectives on the state of journalism, and this empowered us to use these testimonies to form our own conclusions.I also think all of the writing assignments clearly signaled relevance to the class, and they helped to apply and facilitate our learning. The individual prompts were also well-timed with what we were currently learning about or where we were in the course syllabus/timeline.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was undoubtedly stimulating. The variety of guest speakers with different backgrounds and political leanings combined with the immersive lectures gave us a broad and enriched perspective on the ethical problems of journalism. Most lectures were audiovisual in nature, and the readings and writing assignments we were assigned pertained directly to how we as students consume media and the behind-the-scenes of the media we consume. Finally, we were continuously encouraged to ask and answer questions, which made the class interactive.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

This course is purposefully broad and covers a myriad of ethical issues in journalism. Continue to consume a variety of media and news sources as you go through the course, and use that knowledge to find out what you're passionate about further investigating. Then ask Bill or your peers!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class can be difficult and at some times depressing. Journalism largely contributes to the divide in our country, and try to fix it can be a bit of a downer. However, regular experienced guest speakers and the enthusiasm from classmates made for a truly interesting class that is worth taking. You'll be challenged to reframe your thinking in many ways and consider tough topics.

response_text: I learned a lot about the world of journalism and the current issues the industry faces with trust and retaining ethical standards of content that reflect well on journalism as a whole. I also learned about different mediums of journalism and how to write better papers.

response_text:
I learned a lot more about misinformation in the news, which I had not previously known a lot about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better understanding of the media & journalism industry, a deep dive into some of the issues surrounding trust & polarization, writing tips, creative solutions-oriented thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical media literacy skills, ability to write lively and compelling papers, interesting approaches to media and business

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed an appreciation for the role of local news in my community.
I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

response_text: I really enjoyed all of the guest speakers and found their insights into specific aspects of journalism that they had developed expertise in to help facilitate my learning. I also enjoyed when assignments varied in their medium, whether that be podcast, documentary, film, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Bill made this class perfectly structured to incorporate guest speakers in with lectures in order to keep the content engaging and fresh for students. I guest speakers should remain a cornerstone of this course for future years.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really loved all the interesting and diverse guest speakers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion component of the class made the course stimulating, and I also enjoyed how Professor Adair evolved the class due to the constantly-changing news environment.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because of the creative class environment, lively debates, and speakers. It lacked a bit of academic rigor, however. More papers or readings that we engage with directly during class could have heightened the quality of some of our discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Challenging status quo of journalism and reflecting on how we can improve journalism and products of journalism.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating due to the wide variety of speakers and topics discussed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved the chance to engage in deep discussions about what we read. Hearing everyone's perspectives and potential solutions was great. A bit more diversity of opinion in the class might have improved discussions even more, but I think that's hard to get at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Guest speakers taught me a lot, but felt like some class lectures were not as stimulating as they could have been. Would have liked to see current events consistently integrated into slides/lectures, as opposed to just having one or two lectures dedicated to dissecting Olivia Nuzzi and Mark Robinson or the election. Also could have included pieces from the Daily Show, Fox & Friends, etc. Also, Phil Boyce was an excellent guest and I would have liked to see some more conservative speakers or assignments from/for conservative sources (though I appreciate it's probably difficult to find people willing to talk to a liberal Duke class).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The range of topics from local to big media and specifically the interaction with guest speakers made it very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the content assigned was very stimulating, as well as the conversations in class and questions asked to the guest speakers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated hearing the opinions of my peers and would encourage opportunities for us to talk to each other rather than at the teacher. This being said, I think we would've benefited more from group discussions and breaking off into smaller groups so that everyone was able to share their ideas and it could've been more conversational rather than one voice in a big lecture, one at a time. That would've at least been more stimulating to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed how relevant this class was. In my experience, it is rare to be in a class in which the professor is consistently addressing current issues/events. I especially enjoyed this given the recent election cycle. Keeping up with current events is something that I value, so being able to do so through assignments, lectures, and class discussions was highly enjoyable. My only suggestion would be to make the powerpoints more engaging or perhaps limiting them altogether. Although I understand the informational value they bring, they can also not be particularly intellectually stimulating when taking up the entire class period.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I do feel fortunate as this semester felt the most important and relevant to take this class as it was in the months leading up to what feels like the most important election in our lifetimes. Everything we discussed felt perfectly timed and helped inform me to what was going on in the world around me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- Good course
- Content seems professor oriented (ours had a lot about fact-checking)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it. It's not too difficult, but it's a great intro to the journalism and news field. Bill is very good at convincing you that this is definitely not the last class in the department you should take

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a must take course  if you are interested in journalism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course for students taking the JAM minor and also students like myself who are not. It's not the hardest class, but it will require you to be intentional about the three big assignments it has, and it will also require you to be engaged with the material during class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take the course with Bill if you're specifically interested in his work with fact checking because that ends up taking a good chunk of the class. This is not the most rigorous course but it is unique in its level of exposure to great speakers and untouched topics of trust and business in media.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to be more informed about politics and journalism you should take this class. Opens your eyes to what is out there and keeps you informed on how to consume news the right way. I believe this is a very important skill to have especially as a young adult going through college and hopefully an election year like we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy it! And speak a lot more in class, I think that proves to be quite important.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class! It might be my favorite at Duke so far (and it convinced me to declare a journalism minor).  Bill is a fantastic professor who makes lectures fun and will introduce you to a variety of interesting topics. You'll learn a lot about media and meet super cool people in the industry. I also made good friends in the class thanks to the small-group environment and open discussions. As an added bonus, the workload was always very manageable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have any mild interest in journalism or want to just try it out this course is perfect to begin. It allows you to gain so much knowledge about media and dive into all the complexities and implications. My bet is even if you start with a small interest in journalism you will definitely end with a large one after taking this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you are outspoken enough of a student to participate in this course and get the most out of it. Perhaps take it with people with whom you feel supported.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that though the content is fun and engaging at times, you should see if your learning style will fit with the instructor that is taking it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a good course to take if you enjoy politics and are liberal.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT! You absolutely will not regret it. This has been my favorite class and professor I have ever had in my four years at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to diversify my news diet, how to read news more critically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about current news topics and the evolution of the media and the news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different types of reporting (opinion, profile, TV broadcasting, etc.) and the practices and ethics that come with both. I really enjoyed learning about journalists think through the purpose and impacts of their job, such as our class discussions about what is truth, the relationship between subject-journalist-audience, and how information is presented. ALSO this class made me so much more aware of the news, and I think the news quizzes were such a great idea and absolutely essential to the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. How the Trump administration is attacking the mainstream media 2. How journalists approach the ability to respect and protect their sources and also their responsibility to hold systems/governments accountable 3.The effects of declining trust in the media

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: instructor brought in many guest speakers, many big names in the industry, which was super unique and engaging. I felt very lucky to be exposed to those people

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
